subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);

messageBody:
Hi Bob,

Mock objects are not going to help you much there, especially if "
System.exit()" must remain as is in the code to be tested.

I would suggest to use your own security manager and disallow this call,
which should then be turned into an exception that you can catch at a higher
level.

Let me know how it works for you...

--
Cedric
http://testng.org


On 9/7/06, Bob Russell <bob_russell0@...> wrote:
>
>
> I'm involved on a project as the QA. To improve my development
> skills and my JUnit skills, I am writing some JUnit tests. Today, I
> found that the developer had implemented System.exit(n) throughout
> the application whenever there was a trapped exception.
>
> Now, the requirements call for the application to return some exit
> code telling any downstream processes whether this application was
> 100% successful with no warnings (rc=0), 100% successful with
> warnings (rc=4), not successful at all (rc=8). However, the only
> java mechanism for reporting return codes is System.exit(n), based on
> my use of Google.
>
> My JUnit dilemma then, is that System.exit(n) gives the required
> application behavior but doesn't seem to be good for running JUnit
> tests from a test suite since System.exit(n) ends the JVM.
>
> Does anyone have any insights they can share? Since this is my first
> post to this forum, I'm happy to Google some more if you'll only give
> me some keyword hint(s) beyond what I've already tried: "java exit
> code".
>
> Thanks!
